rawLines.text: Sean, it's a pleasure to be here with
you and to be able to talk with you
about Palunteer, a company I've seen
innovating on the battlefield uh and at
home. So, let me get right to it. This
audience heard Vice President Vance this
morning speak about an American
renaissance in manufacturing. You've
taken a different uh post-medieval
uh religious metaphor in your writing
about a defense
reformation. Uh you you proposed 18
thesis that you want to nail to the
Pentagon wall uh Martin Luther style uh
demanding innovation. And I want to ask
you to explain for this audience without
going through 18 thesis that the the
core of your basic
question argument. Why does American
defense manufacturing cost so much and
what can be done to start fixing it?
Well, I I think at a very fundamental
level, like the 18 thesis were my 19
years of accumulated experience trying
to crawl across the valley of death and
the reflections from from doing that.
Um, at at a very fundamental level, I
think everyone, you know, the Chinese,
the Russians have given up on communism
except for Cuba and the DoD. You know,
we literally have a five-year plan, the
FIP. Uh, and when I look back at the the
industrial base we used to have when we
were winning World War II in the early
Cold War, it wasn't a defense industrial
base. It was an American industrial
base. Chrysler built cars and missiles.
Ford built satellites until 1990.
General Mills, the serial company, built
torpedoes. There was this way in which
every car, camera, and serial box
Americans bought was actually
subsidizing the R&D around our national
security. As a consequence of having won
the Cold War, we got more and more
comfortable putting our defense
industrial base essentially on the
Gopagos Islands. You know, we started a
process that really started in the 70s,
but we kind of really separated
commercial innovation from defense
innovation. Intel in in like I think 68
69% of Intel's sales were to the Apollo
program and to the DoD. But of course,
Intel always aspired to be something
much bigger than that. They were always
playing for a huge commercial market.
And because of that, they drove down the
price performance of integrated circuits
in a way that enabled a saltbreaker one
that enabled fundamental American
prosperity, which is of course the point
of national security. And so I think
this idea of cost plus is just
disastrous for innovation. You know,
there's no leverage in your business. It
it it it robs founders and entrepreneurs
of the necessary incentive to invest
ahead of the curve in the things that
we're going to need. And as someone who
grew up in the shadow of the Space
Coast, I think there's no better example
than than Space Launch. The shuttle used
to cost $50,000 a kilogram to get to
orbit. Cheaper mechanisms we had were
like $20,000 a kilogram. And with
Starship heavy reuse, we're talking
about 10 to 20 bucks. I'm not no zeros
are missing there. Uh and and you need
that sort of incentive, I think, to to
power the American industrial base to to
reestablish deterrence. That's one of
the concepts that we're not really
talking about. It's like I think
empirically we lost deterrence. And we
lost deterrence about a decade ago. We
we had Crimea was annexed. the Iranians
got very very close to a bomb. We've had
a pogram in Israel, you know, and I
think it's a real wakeup call to all of
America. So, you write about how um
going back to the so-called Last Supper
in 1993 when then defense secretary
Perry told uh a bunch of prime
contractors, "Sorry, we're going to have
to shrink the defense base down to a
very few uh number
of prime prime contractors."
um that that we now have this system
with with just a few companies that are
able to navigate the rules uh sort of
elaborate procedures of Pentagon
procurement. And one question I had
reading your uh essay which I commend to
everybody um is whether you can uh get
to the kind of renaissance in defense
manufacturing you're talking about
without breaking this system of Pentagon
rules and procurement which is just
elaborate. You know every one of those
rules has a reason uh every member of
Congress has a particular reason to
object to dismantling a piece of it. So,
how are you going to how are you going
to do that in this area? We're watching
Doge try to attack uh bureaucracy uh
across the government. The Pentagon is
particularly difficult because it's so
tightly interwoven. How are your your
company other smaller startup companies
going to break through? Well, I think
this room is a reason for immense
optimism. So, I think the real
consequence of the Last Supper, it's in
many ways we've lost the plot on what
happened. the the the fil explanation is
we went from 51 primes down to five.
That meant there was a lack of
competition in the industrial base and
that's why everything sucks. And I I
don't think that actually gets at the
root of the issue. So we went from SP
for every dollar we were spending we
started spending 33 cents very
substantial budget reduction. It
basically happened all in one year and
that consolidation breeds conformity
because we forget that it wasn't Northup
Grumman. It was Jack Northrup and Leroy
Grumman. that actually there were these
larger than-l life entrepreneurs,
innovators, engineers who were really
driving this industrial base and this
consolidation really drove them out of
it. It was the beginning of the
financialization of defense and a whole
different sort of shape of defense
company that came out of this almost you
know very artificial consolidation
process. Uh the reason to be optimistic
is that you now have Palmer Lucky. You
now have hundreds of founders and
entrepreneurs that are back on the
playing field with wildly heterodox
ideas that are not just being yesmen to
what the program offices are asking for,
but actually investing their own capital
into R&D, you know, not on the cost plus
addiction cycle to deliver fundamental
innovation. And that's what it used to
look like when we were building ICBMs.
The services were competing against each
other. And this the the greatest loss of
of you know, we tell ourselves this
thing that we can't afford duplication.
And that's one of the ways in which we
implicitly are shorting the free market
system that it's not duplication, it's
competition. And do you think
competition is going to drive to better
cheaper ideas? Do you believe technology
is a force for transformation or is it
kind of beside the point? But I want to
come back to the phrase that you used at
the beginning which I'm sure is familiar
to most people in the audience the
valley of death which is what uh people
trying to sell to the Pentagon to
describe as the gap between development
and there's a lot of innovative
development DARPA and so many other
agencies have tried to sponsor good
ideas and production at scale deployment
throughout uh military service. I'm
still not sure I understand how how you
propose to get across that valley of
death. Yeah. At Palunteer over the last
two decades, there are probably like 10
major efforts I've been involved with
that are really going from 0ero to one
to one to end. The first couple times I
went through that uh it sucked and I
couldn't it was it interpersonally
frictionful. The people on both sides of
this divide hated each other and there's
a human proclivity to say like oh there
must be a process. there must be some
way that I can make this transition less
painful. And I came to the conclusion
around the third or fourth time like no
no there is no process. Any attempt to
put a process on this just kills the
innovation that actually it is a messy
chaotic process to get from this side to
that side and you have to get through it
with like sheer will you know it takes
uh it takes a rick overlike figure. It
takes real leadership. There's no amount
of process that will do it. So I think
actually the problem is that we've been
praying at the altar of process for too
long and then we keep adding barnacles
of bureaucracy to that process thinking
that it will make it better and it only
makes it fail with more certainty. When
David Packard Silicon Valley founder
created the the 5000 series it was seven
pages. It's now more than 2,000 pages.
That's a compounded growth rate of 11% a
year. You know that's pretty you know
it's the only way in which the DoD is
beating the market. So, so again to come
back to the fundamental question, do you
have to uh have new legislation or some
other way to essentially shred the the
layers and layers of
requirements? The process is all
codified in law. How do you how do you
get some of it statutory, a lot of it is
regulation, a lot of it is kind of
self-imposed barnacles bureaucracy. And
I think the answer to what ails us here,
how you break that monop monopsiny is
strong leadership. We have to give
people discretion just like we would in
our companies when you're betting on a
product leader or an engineering leader.
You know, they're going to have to learn
from their mistakes. I think I think uh
things like DAPA or where you're
rotating around our uniform uh service
members every two to three years is a
disaster. You're not even in the role
long enough to know you made a mistake
that you're going to learn from. And I
think this stuff compounds over time. So
I I think it it really does. It's not
about more defense reform. It's not
about statutory changes. It's about
empowering our people and betting on
them. So when you think about the
distribution of outcomes, you can't lop
off all of the bad outcomes without also
lpping off all the good outcomes. That
that's how that's how it works. So we've
kind of locked ourselves into, you know,
we've constrained ourselves into having
mediocre outcomes at best. So let let's
talk a little bit about uh your company,
Palunteer.
Um share with this audience how your
software products can help uh a smaller
defense company, a company that wants to
innovate um be more productive and have
opportunities in this space that
wouldn't otherwise be available. Well,
one of the things I'm most excited about
and where I'm spending a lot of my time
is on this offering that we call warp
speed. So for the better part of 15
years, we, you know, h half of our
business is really commercial. And we
build every Airbus, every Chrysler,
every BMW, every HD Hyundai ship. Um,
for a lot of that time, we've kind of
had to to to borrow a phrase from our
adversary, you know, hide our strength
and bite our time because it it's been
very clear that the manufacturing stack
that legacy manufacturers use doesn't
work. If you go to the factory floor in
Detroit, they're so proud of their ERP
system, but on the factory floor,
they're using Excel. So, how good could
it really be? There was a huge
marktomarket moment with with COVID in
the supply chain crisis. You know,
people had been spending tens of
billions of dollars in their uh supply
chain software and it all fell over like
a paper tiger. If you go back to the
earnings calls, what were CEOs talking
about as the tech investments that saved
them? Zoom Teams. I mean, what an
indictment of the software industrial
complex. And that was the first moment
that we could be more honest that we
think the software stack has failed and
that you know you might be really wedded
to your legacy providers but you need to
reimagine this whole thing. What's
really exciting about the present moment
is for the modern American manufacturing
companies the people that are in this
room they already know the software
stack is a fraud. Uh there's a reason
Elon built his own stack from scratch to
do this. So we're talking about people
who grew up directly or indirectly in
the school of Tesla and SpaceX and
already know they got to reimagine how
to do this. So there's been a a huge
opportunity to help people integrate the
whole process from PLM to ERP to MEES to
their CRM to actually give them real
agility in terms of how they build what
they're building and how quickly they
can iterate on designs and manage the
cost of those changes and how it flows
through to delivery. So you know Andrew
has built their production
infrastructure entirely on top or
manufacturing production infrastructure
entirely on top of our offering here.
Shield AI, Eperis, uh, Sale Drone,
Seronic, and I I think that's it's just
it's a massive accelerant to their
ability to scale as the government
starts making big bets in doing this.
So, take this a little further. I've
talked with Palmer Lucky about his idea
that you need to fundamentally change
how you manufacture things for the
defense market to bring cost down. uh
that you know we're building these
ridiculously exquisite is the phrase the
Pentagon always uses uh Cadillacs when
what we need are you know kind of lots
of of lower cost um products with with
interchangeable parts. Give us a sense
of of how that manufacturing revolution
to drive down cost standardized
production might work and what role your
company would play in it. Well uh you
you need to be able to design. So you
right now our whole system works where
because we've divided up development
from production, you get to one
prototype of something that's truly
exquisite and the science and
engineering behind it is amazing, but
you're going to be able to build 10 of
them and you may not even be able to
afford 10 of them. Uh and in the
commercial world, the word design for
manufacturability is how you do
everything, you know. So you're actually
thinking about the fact that you need
10,000 of these things up front and how
you design it and then how you iterate
on the design is always about
incrementally improving your ability to
produce those things at scale and the
cost at which it cost it to to make
those things. Uh and and so a lot of
this is about closing that cycle time
and software you think about it like a
CI check and when you change your design
what are the consequences for
manufacturability? How do you actually
colllocate your R&D engineers closer to
the factory floor so that you're you're
changing that feedback loop in a very
fundamental way. A lot of that breaks
the conventional thinking in the
Pentagon where you want to like lock in
your design and then just go build these
things. And I think some of that is just
an opioid. It's it's a desire to avoid
pain, the complexity of making changes.
But when you do that actually, you
realize you've changed your frig design
in a way that now the center of gravity
is completely wrong and the thing might
not float. But by the time you figure
that out, you're it's too late. You
needed to figure that out at at the
point of design, not at the point of
production.
So you talked uh earlier about some of
these uh
charismatic founder figures. Um you have
a a a blog on Substack uh that I think
you call first breakfast. Yeah. The
antidote to the last supper. So the last
supper and then now we're going to have
the first breakfast. Um but uh one of
the features of this if if people
haven't looked at it is something you
call heroes and and heretics.
uh and it's people you know like these
uh oddball uh you know sometimes
doineering founders some of the people
you profile are the famous Admiral
Heyman Rickover Senator John McCain who
so many of us remember fondly Kelly
Johnson who built the locked skunk works
uh air force colonel John Boyd who
coined the term the oda loop and you go
into who who who the the person who
figured out the odal loop was. But I
want to ask you um as you've reviewed
these extraordinary
personalities, what they have in common
in terms of their um intellectual traits
um the way that they confronted uh the
bureaucracies in which they operated.
What what is it if you were to give two
or three uh personality traits that
makes people like this capable of such
extraordinary performance? I I I think
they're founders. I mean, to use a word
that I think people in Silicon Valley
would recognize and uh for those of I'm
I'm not a founder, you know, I've worked
I've worked for incredible founders, but
there's a huge amount of vision. Uh
there's a huge amount of talent. Uh
there's an ability to manage the talent
around them and almost create that
reality distortion field. I think what
they also have in common, the reason I
called it heretics and heroes is that um
they are difficult people. You know,
Boyd was famously abrasive. There's a
reason he couldn't make general. Rick
Overber required the protection of the
entirety of Congress. But the nuclear
navy he built is one of our last
remaining asymmetric advantages even
now, even though he did that thing in
the 60s. You know, it's it's truly
incredible. Danny Gold, you know, when
he built the Iron Dome, technically it
was like an illegal procurement and they
were ready to throw him in jail.
Fortunately for him, I think it was well
timed. There was a missile barrage where
the dome performed excellently and he
became a national hero. You know, Edward
Hall, I wouldn't recommend anyone do
this, but Edward Hall had to fake a
Soviet intelligence report about
missiles in order to get the Minute Man
funded. There's a way in which like our
anodine retelling of history is like,
look, if you just follow the process,
everything works. But I think if we look
at our really big successes, everyone
had to break the process, including Bill
Perry. He he got stealth done, he got
GPS done, he got those things done
around PPBE. Bill Perry was looking at
the problem. He said, "Hey, I can either
fix the system and I'm going to get
bogged down in trench warfare and
probably fail or I can go around the
system and make sure the most important
things that the nation requires do
succeed." So, um, if if if there, you
know, you'd have rules for uh founders,
rules for for heretics for right now,
uh, what would two or three of them be?
What are the things that people in this
audience, the the people they work with
uh need to do um that that will allow
them to innovate um in a world that
still has so many obstacles?
To to a delayed answer to your question
which answers this question as well is
the primacy of winning. You know what
what all these people have in common is
that they were working backwards from
what was required to win. And as we look
we are in the 11th hour here. You know
how prepared are we for 2027? How
prepared are we for a world where we've

time in a way that provides any

up every day trying to answer for

of winning. Um, we have just uh over

and to everybody in the audience and
that's AI. Uh from where you sit as

extraordinarily advanced uh tech company
company what's the AI challenge that um
interests you the most? Uh, and I'd also

or or difficulty slashdanger
uh that concerns you most. If you think
about AI, you can divide it up into
supply and demand. And um I think we we
spent a lot of time and capital and we
need to continue to spend more on the
supply side building the models. But uh
we have not spent enough time or energy
organizing around the demand side. How

think the opportunity actually is. Uh at
the beginning of the AI revolution,
there's kind of a question of what's
going to be most valuable. Is it going
to be building a co-pilot that augments
an existing human's efforts maybe 20%
50% better or is it going to be
automation autonomy that makes them 200

then if you think about that journey, we
can reason about it by analogy by
looking at self-driving cars. You know,
we had a self-driving car that drove
through the desert 120 miles in 2005,
the DARPA Grand Challenge winner. What
have we been doing for 20 years? Uh I I
think one way of framing it is we've
been handling edge cases. You know,
there there's just a lot of edge cases
between that and a commercial
self-driving car service, which arguably
we now have. uh and I think as we think
about the the journey for enterprise
autonomy that's actually what we need to
be focused on which is how do we build
the infrastructure that enables us to
accumulate and handle the edge cases
where are the big national investments
that we actually need to make so that we
can get really good at doing this I
think if we just divide this up there's
a reason that there are only a few big
winners in the commercial self-driving
car space uh the government probably
needs to make a concerted effort to
collect every sort of AI int if you will
every sort of sensor inference
that's happening at the edge today. We
throw that away. And if we really want
to outpace our adversary, if we want to
have the best possible udaloop, which is
really what drives deterrence, we need
to to really organize around this
problem. So that's that's what we should

the thing that we shouldn't do? And by

they needed six months of rest for every

there's something about if you're really
that the right way to think about how
are we going to oversee AI has to come
from the PR practitioners who are at the

there's been a lot of historic hand
